newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil shrs end fractionally higher in weak trade.
newsitem.headline: Brazil shrs end fractionally higher in weak trade.

text.p: Brazilian stocks ended slightly higher, tracking the Dow Jones' mild rise, but trading was at a near standstill due to a lack of local or foreign market-moving news, brokers said.
"The market was very weak," said one dealer. "We have no relevant economic or political news."
The Sao Paulo bourse's Bovespa index of 49 most traded shares edged up 69 points to close at 62,769 points, up 0.11 percent.
Turnover was an anemic 165 million reais, one of the lowest volumes of the year.
Brokers said trade was moribund due to a lack of news, local or foreign. "There's nothing going on," brokers said.
Brazilian stocks dipped at the open, but remained mostly stable through the day, shadowing the Dow Jones and keeping a watchful eye on developments in Iraq, they added.
"The market is going very, very sideways these days," one dealer said. "Iraq hurt on the first day, but not today, and otherwise the market is closely following the Dow."
The Bovespa's rise was led by Banco do Brasil common BBp.SA, up 5.1 percent to end at 10.50 reais. Steelmaker CSN common led losers, falling 3.4 percent to 22.60 reais.
Among blue chips, benchmark Telebras preferred dipped 0.26 percent to close at 75.40 reais, while its common rose 0.80 percent to end at 61.88 reais.
Telebras shares and options comprised 40 percent of the day's total trade, brokers said.
Brazil's state oil monopoly Petrobras preferred ended the day up 0.83 percent at 121.00 reais and state mining giant Vale do Rio Doce preferred climbed 1.02 percent to 19.85 reais.
But blue chip power firm Eletrobras dipped 0.36 percent to end at 280.00 reais despite a 0.78 percent rise in the bolsa's Electrical Energy Index of nine most-liquid power shares to 1,591 points.
